title: Ex vivo two-photon imaging of whole-mount skeletal muscles to visualize stem cell behavior
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Muscle injury, isolation, and fixation
Timing: 3 days
This section describes steps to perform point injury to muscle and isolate skeletal muscle samples for later whole-mount imaging. 2–6-month-old male Pax7EGFP mice are used in this protocol. Skeletal muscle injury is induced by intramuscular injection of notexin (NTX), a snake venom toxin that causes myotoxic damage.28[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib28] If MuSC number and cell morphology in steady state conditions is desired, then the muscle injury can be omitted.
Optional: Inject notexin (NTX) to Pax7EGFP mice for skeletal muscle injury.
Anesthetize Pax7EGFP mice with isoflurane in an anesthesia induction chamber.
After the mouse is fully sedated, transfer the mouse to a flat surface and position the nose cone around the snout and mouth of the mouse to keep it anesthetized.
Shave the hair off the hindlimb with an Electric Razor.
Wipe the hindlimbs of the mice with ethanol wipes.
Inject 10 μL (10 μg/mL) of NTX diluted in PBS intramuscularly into the tibialis anterior muscle at one site per muscle (10 μL per muscle). The needle for injection should first poke through the fascia but then stay at the top of the muscle.
Critical: The needle can be inserted at approximately 45°. The injury should be close to the top of the muscle for easier visualization by two-photon microscopy. Otherwise, the signal intensity of cells within the injury and second harmonics of the fiber start to disappear at about 400 μm.
Allow the mice to recover post-injury depending on the desired time frame after injury.
Following IACUC guidelines, euthanize Pax7EGFP mice.
Collect tibialis anterior (TA) muscle from uninjured and injured Pax7EGFP mice.
Position the mouse spine on a Styrofoam dissection board, secure limbs with a 21G needle, and spray the mouse with 70% (vol/vol) ethanol.

Use forceps to pinch the center of the mouse belly skin and cut an opening horizontally. Peel off the leg skin by pulling the opening in opposite directions.
Carefully remove the fascia and use sharp forceps to expose the underneath TA muscle.
Run the sharp tip of the forceps underneath the TA muscle to detach the muscle from the tibia.
Cut the distal TA tendon, and while holding it, use a dissection scissor to cut the muscle along the longitudinal line of the TA muscle. Carefully remove TA at its proximal attachment.
Place the muscle in a 6 cm dish containing 4% paraformaldehyde/1× phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) buffer on ice.
Wrap the 6 cm dish containing TA muscles with aluminum foil.
Note: The aluminum foil is used to protect samples containing internal fluorescence from too much light exposure before imaging.
Place the 6 cm dish in an orbital shaker in the cold room (4°). Leave the TA samples in their current condition for 2 h to fix the muscle samples.
Note: Fixation at 4 degree is recommended to better preserve fluorescence intensity and reduce background fluorescence. Too long fixation time (longer than 4 h for TA muscle) will quench the green fluorescent protein signal.
After fixation, aspirate 4% paraformaldehyde from the 6 cm dish and wash the muscles with 3 mL of 1× phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) for 3 times.
Preserve the muscles in 3 mL of 1× phosphate-buffered saline (PBS).
Pause point: The muscles can be preserved in PBS in the cold room for weeks before imaging.
Note: Too long cold room storage will cause increased autofluorescence. It is recommended to image the tissue as soon as possible and within 1–3 weeks after fixation to minimize the potential differences in fluorescence intensity.
Imaging chamber preparation
Timing: <1 h

Fixed muscles were mounted on a custom-made polycarbonate chamber and immersed in 1× PBS, and a coverslip was lowered from the top to close the chamber.
Create a polycarbonate window with the following dimensions: Length: 25 mm, Width: 25 mm, Height: 3 mm or 3.5 mm, width between inner and outer square: 5 mm (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A). troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].

(A) Dimensions of custom-made polycarbonate chamber.
(B–E) Key steps for creating chamber.
(F and G) Steps of TA muscle embedding.
Cut a piece of filter paper based on the size of the inner square (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Apply Elmer’s rubber cement to the back of the polycarbonate window (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C) and attach the window to the plus slide of the Superfrost plus microscopy slide to create a polycarbonate chamber (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D).
Place the obtained filter paper inside the chamber (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]E) to decrease the movement of muscle samples relative to the chamber.
Use forceps to place one TA muscle inside the chamber carefully (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]F).
Apply Elmer’s rubber cement to the top of the polycarbonate window to glue the coverslip to the window.
Use transfer pipets to fill the polycarbonate chamber with 1× PBS.
Carefully lower the cover glass on top of the window to close the chamber (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]G).
Use the sharp tip of the forceps to push gently on top of the cover glass and use Kim Wipe to remove excess mounting media (1× PBS). The whole setup is finished and ready for two-photon imaging.

Note: The current imaging chamber setup is used for upright microscope. If inverted microscope is used, the imaging chamber setup would be a little different: keep steps 14, 16, 18, 19, 20, and 21, and skip steps 15 and 17. For step 18, place the TA muscle upside down, so that the anterior of the muscle faced down, and use Elmer’s rubber cement to attach the muscle to the Superfrost plus microscope slide to decrease the movement of muscle samples relative to the polycarbonate chamber.
Two-photon ex vivo imaging
Timing: 3–4 h per sample
Perform two-photon imaging of whole-mount uninjured or injured TA muscle and visualize the structure of interest. This should be specific to each research group. In our case, we image muscle fiber with second harmonics (SHG) and muscle stem cells expressing green fluorescent proteins in Pax7EGFP mice.
Turn on the microscope controller, confocal unit, Leica software (LAS X), PC, and tunable multiphoton (MP) laser for imaging.
Move the motorized stage from the preparation area to the imaging area. Place the chamber containing the muscle sample on the motorized stage. Adjust the XY position of the microscope motorized platform so that the muscle sample is directly underneath the lens and secure the chamber by tightening the screw (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).

Deposit distilled water on top of the coverslip for the water-immersion lens.
Adjust the height of the lens to find focus (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Turn off room lights, turn on wide-field epifluorescence, and use the eyepiece to find focus. troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Note: To avoid bleaching, keep the epifluorescence at the lowest power.
Turn off the epifluorescence shutter and cover the microscope with a blackout chamber or blackout cloth (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
Note: Avoid intense light from surrounding to enter the microscope.
Turn on the MP laser shutter. Set the laser wavelength at 910 nm for green fluorophore and SHG.
Select the imaging area and conditions. troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting], troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Set the laser power at 13% for a start.
Set the detector gain to 100%. If the signal remains low, slowly increase the laser power.
Turn on tilescan and z-stack and adjust XYZ position to find the field of interest where muscle stem cells are visible and lower than the collagen deposition layer.
Set scan settings of LAS X (Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C–2E).
Format 1024 × 1024.
Speed: 400 Hz.
Bidirectional: ON Phase X: −33.04.
Zoom factor: 1.5.
Image size: 369.05 μm × 369.05 μm, Pixel Size 360.75 μm × 360.75 μm.
Line Average: 2.
Tilescan field size: 3 × 4; merge images by advanced statistical stitching.
Set the upper limits of a z-stack, ensuring the upper limits are lower than the collagen deposition layer. Set lower limits of a z-stack before the muscle cell signal disappears. Start the z-stack acquisition with the 1 or 1.5 μm step size.
Note: It usually takes two hours to finish scanning for an image with a z-stack about 100 μm in-depth and tilescan with field size 3 × 4.
Save the original file (lif format) to a hard drive for further data analysis.

Pause point: Image analysis can be conducted at any time after the imaging.
Image analysis using Fiji software
Timing: 5–8 h per image
Acquired optical sections from two-photon microscopy are analyzed in Fiji software. To define the muscle stem cell (MuSC) number in the TA muscle, acquired optical sections are stacked in Fiji, and MuSCs are counted and normalized to the volume stacked. To quantify the length and number of the protrusions of MuSC, minimum 100 MuSCs per image should be analyzed using the Simple Neurite Tracer (SNT) plugin in Fiji. MuSC circularity/aspect ratio, circularity, and orientation ratio are measured using set measurements and the angle tool in Fiji. Cells are defined as misaligned with myofiber if the angle between the cell body and myofiber is greater than a 15-degree angle, and the ratio is calculated as the number of cells misaligned divided by the total number of cells per cell type.
Load the original image into Fiji software (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A) using File > Open (choose split channels) and save the image as tiff format using File > Save as > tiff.

Mark individual cells for analysis using the "multi-point" function (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Click to show the label on all slices.
Only select cells if all details are visible.
Save the numbered image and the numbering system as a selection (.roi file).
Create maximum projection of the image (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
Go to Image > Stacks > Z project.
Choose Max intensity.

Save the Max projection as a tiff file.
Load saved number selection by dragging the ROI file to Fiji software.
Setup the measurement parameter by clicking Analyze > set measurement > click area and shape descriptors.
Manually draw a circle encompassing the cell body of the muscle stem cell to obtain cell area and circularity (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D). troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Use the freehand selection tool to circle the cell body.
Click Analyze > Measure to get area and circularity results.
Export data to copy into Excel to the corresponding cell number.
To assess whether the cells are aligned with the myofiber, use the angle tool to measure the angle between the cell body and the myofiber. If the angle is larger than a 15-degree, the cell is considered as misaligned with the fiber. The misaligned ratio is calculated as the number of cells misaligned divided by the total number of cells per cell type.
Download the Neuroanatomy plugin to Fiji software for measurement of protrusion length by update function.
Open the Neuroanatomy plugin and load the numbered tiff file by:
Plugins > Neuroanatomy >SNT > select numbered tiff file as the image file
Select only XY view in the user interface.
Select the path of protrusions and obtain individual protrusion protrusions by:
Move along the Z direction and click at the beginning and the end of each protrusion to create a protrusion path.
In the Path Manager, click on the path and obtain protrusion by Tag > Morphometry > Length.
Export data to copy into Excel to the corresponding cell number.

Note: In quiescence, MuSCs could have 0–9 protrusions. We have described in detail the morphological and functional properties for each MuSC subtype in Ma et al.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] Based on the starting position of the protrusions, this imaging protocol allows for further characterization as follows:
Primary protrusions: extruding from the cell body.
Secondary protrusions: branching from Primary protrusions.
Tertiary protrusions: branching from secondary protrusions.
Quaternary protrusions: branching from tertiary protrusions.
Secondary, Tertiary, and Quaternary protrusions are called branches. Branches should be marked in the Excel file.
To calculate the number of MuSCs per volume, find a cuboid volume of the image that is filled with muscle fibers, calculate the volume and make a maximum projection, and count the total number of MuSCs in the cuboid, and calculate the final number of MuSCs per volume.
Find an area full of fibers and use the rectangle tool to select and crop the region of interest.
Obtain dimensions by selecting Image > Show info > Width, Height, Z-step size (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).

Select the Z sections of muscle and create maximum projection for the volume of interest (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
Obtain the depth of the volume of interest by multiplying Z-step size with the number of Z sections used to create volume of interest.
Count all the MuSCs on the maximum projection image by Plugins > Analyze > Cell Counter (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C).
Export data and copy it into Excel.
The MuSC numbers were normalized to 1 μm3 volume of muscle fibers.

Analyze the data in Excel and graph datasets as desired in GraphPad Prism. Data can be grouped as number of cells per volume, MuSC composition based on the number of protrusions, MuSC misalignment ratio, MuSC protrusion length, MuSC area, and MuSC circularity.
